posts.name: Sparks333
posts.cooked:
Hello,

I have a little experimental sensor I’ve been hacking together, essentially a low-level sensor that I’m managing with a RP2350 as an intermediary and transmitting the data back to the Rio via a serial interface. Ideally, since the data packet is always the same size (albeit quite large, around 700 bytes), I’d like to use the SPI port, and the RP2350 has a perfectly good slave-capable SPI port that can run at the same max speed as the Rio, namely 4 Mbps. The trouble is twofold:

The SPI port library is pretty poorly documented and seems geared specifically to run the ADIS SPI Gyro that was popular before the CAN gyros and AHRS devices we see today

The SPI port library is pretty poorly documented and seems geared specifically to run the ADIS SPI Gyro that was popular before the CAN gyros and AHRS devices we see today

The Java library (haven’t checked with the C++ libs) silently truncates all transfers over 8 bytes. To wit, in SPI.class (line 243):

The Java library (haven’t checked with the C++ libs) silently truncates all transfers over 8 bytes. To wit, in SPI.class (line 243):

Note that the underlying call has a silent cast to byte, and that’s not the worst of it - SPIJNI.spiTransaction itself has this in the documentation text:

Not only does it cast to byte, it turns out the only valid values are 0-7.

Attempting to send significantly more data (say, 700 bytes) just causes it to transmit at most 8 bytes and then return, which feels like the wrong kind of action to be taking.

It does appear as though there is an automatic SPI engine that may allow for greater data transfer sizes (from older threads it seems like it may be stuck at 128 bytes max), but at any rate that is a bit more complex, and I was hoping to test out the concept with a simple blocking polled version to start.

Any hints on trying to transmit gobs of data through SPI? I’d really prefer not to knock this into a higher level protocol, but it seems like SPI has been orphaned on the Rio.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.custom_user_title: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: This seems to been an artificial historical limit.  We’ll implement a fix to allow for the full size allowed by Linux (which appears to be a page, so probably 4096 bytes).

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
To add on, the byte case for Java from 700 actually casts to -68. So we’d have to do a lot more digging to figure out why that results in 8, but instead we’ll probably just fix it like Peter said.

One thing to be careful about, is even at 4 Mbps, 700 bytes is about 1.5ms just in transfer time. That should be fine, but something to be careful about as SPI transactions are blocking calls.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: PR opened: [hal] SPI: Remove byte limit on size by PeterJohnson · Pull Request #7774 · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

link_counts.title: [hal] SPI: Remove byte limit on size by PeterJohnson · Pull Request #7774 · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub

posts.name: Sparks333
posts.cooked:
Excellent, thank you so much for the quick fix! I’ll test it out as soon as I can.

In terms of the time it takes to transfer, yeah, I kinda forgot the first rule of comms, never send more than you need to - I was being clever and thought I could save the Rio some computation by pre-computing a bunch of stuff and sending it over, but thinking more on it I either need to send enough from the Rio that the coprocessor can provide a higher-level, more abstract result, or do a lot more calculation on the Rio. Either way, I think 8 bytes isn’t enough, but I bet I could get it in 128 pretty comfortably. In any case, this ought to open up a lot more possibilities with the SPI port!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.custom_user_title: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.name: Sparks333
posts.cooked:
In regards to why 700 became 8, I don’t have a wonderful answer for you, but to be precise I was attempting to send over 772 bytes - that seems like it should modulo to 4 instead of 8, plus it kind of seems like that HAL call is zero-indexed, so it just raises more questions, but I didn’t want you trying to make 700 get to 8 without more details.

EDIT: Nope, I was off, I was attempting 776 bytes, that does modulo to 8 and is the likely reason why that ended up working the way it did. Still doesn’t explain why the HAL call comments say 0-7 and yet did a transfer of 8 when 8 was sent…

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.custom_user_title: Robot Whisperer and Source of Bad Ideas

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
It wouldn’t be modulo 8, it’d be a negative number. byte is a signed type. And it looks like a negative number would get converted back into a very large positive number at the lower levels. I would have expected an error there and not a transfer of 8, but its hard to tell.

And the real fix is to just not let the number go negative. Which is what we did.
